awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: A Decentralized and Differentially Private Framework for Sensing, Operations and Respond Logistics in Large-Scale Vehicle Fleets
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern vehicle fleets are equipped with increasing levels of sensor instrumentation that generate large quantities of data on asset conditions and operational awareness. In recent years, there has been a growing literature on methods that harness this data to provide predictive insights for operations. Taken individually, these methods provide limited improvements to fleet-level decision making. There are significant and dynamic interdependencies in large-scale vehicle fleets that include (i) continuous asset-to-asset interactions in degradation and failure risks, (ii) interactions across vehicles related to operational coordination and use of shared resources (e.g. mission requirements and spare part resources), and (iii) interactions between spare part logistics, maintenance and operations. Additional layers of challenges are introduced through stringent requirements for data residency, privacy, and computational scalability. This NSF project provides a unified predictive-prescriptive framework for vehicle fleet management that integrates (i) sensor-driven predictions on dynamically evolving asset failure probabilities and operational risks, with (ii) adaptive robust optimization models for fleet-level operations, maintenance and respond logistics. Intellectual merits of the project include formulation of sensor-driven risks within decentralized and differentially private mixed integer optimization models; and a parallel development of tailored solution methods. Broader impacts of the project include dissemination of research findings through publications, coursework, conferences and workshops. The project will support summer internships and undergraduate research opportunities, specifically for students from underrepresented communities, to educate the next-generation of engineers for vehicle fleet management.

Harnessing the true value of sensor data in a fleet management application, requires an integrated and detailed modeling of fleet level interactions, along with a seamless integration of sensor-driven sensing, and decision-making capabilities. To address this challenge, this proposal aims to develop a decentralized and differentially private framework for sensor-driven fleet management. In particular, the proposed project (i) integrates sensor-driven asset remaining life distributions within a joint decision optimization model to identify optimal operations, maintenance and spare part logistics schedule, (ii) dynamically models the perceived asset remaining life, failure risks and other operational uncertainties within an adaptive robust reformulation of the fleet management model, and (iii) reformulates the decision model within a decentralized and differentially private coordination mechanism. Significant computational challenges will be addressed through decentralized solution algorithms that leverage on the structure of the proposed decision optimization models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on developing an integrated framework that offers innovative methods to leverage real-time sensor data from vehicular fleets to optimize operations, maintenance and logistics. In line with this overarching goal, the project brought together two integrated modules: a sensor-driven analytics module that offer accurate predictions for health and condition of vehicular components using sensor data, and a decision-making module that utilized these predictions within large-scale decision optimization models to optimize operations, maintenance, and logistics. In line with this, the project outcomes were centered around three main goals. First, sensor-driven predictive models were developed for condition monitoring, degradation and failure analysis, focusing on vehicular components such as batteries. Second, decision optimization models were developed that explicitly model multi-asset degradation interactions, where the failure or degradation of one asset accelerates degradation in others. The proposed optimization models also incorporated operational and logistical interactions, such as vehicle routing. Third, the project extended these models to fleet-level applications by addressing computational scalability and privacy concerns. Privacy enhancing models were developed to improve privacy while providing reliable predictions for heterogeneous assets, such as batteries operating under diverse conditions. Large-scale decision models were formulated to model complex fleet-level operational interactions. To ensure computational efficiency, reformulations and iterative algorithms were implemented, improving scalability and solution accuracy. This work integrated predictive and decision-optimization models and offered scalable and privacy-preserving solutions for fleet management.

The project also resulted in contributions to the academic and industrial communities through the development of novel methodologies. Aligned with the first and third goal, one of the project publications proposed a federated battery diagnosis and prognosis model that addressed scalability and privacy challenges in sensor-driven predictive model deployment for large-scale lithium-ion battery fleets. This work advanced battery health monitoring and lifetime prediction by enabling localized data processing, reducing communication load, and ensuring data residency. It represents a critical step toward sustainable and reliable energy storage solutions for electrified transportation and renewable energy systems. A set of other project products also focused on condition monitoring and degradation modeling for battery systems and addressed other challenges associated with fleet-level deployment. Aligned with the second and third goals, another project outcome introduced a robust optimization model that embeds multi-asset degradation interactions into operations and maintenance decision-making. By integrating degradation dependencies within a general optimization framework, this model synergizes operational efficiency with failure risk management. In another study, a decision making model was developed to integrate sensor-driven failure predictions into a vehicle routing problem with time windows in an effort to enhance fleet maintenance and operations. The work introduced a novel cost function that balanced maintenance scheduling trade-offs and leveraged on the problem structure to develop a novel solution methodology, which achieved significant improvements over commercial solution packages. This approach significantly improved operational efficiency, reduced costs, and enhanced vehicle reliability. 

The project outcomes were incorporated into a graduate level course on cyber physical systems at Wayne State University. The course includes modules and class projects on condition monitoring and decision making that use simplified and focused versions of the proposed research. The preliminary results of this work were also presented in the annual conferences of the Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineering (IISE) and the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences (INFORMS). Research outcomes were made available in open-access archives. Research products were published in leading journals in the field, such as Journal of Power Sources and Cell Reports Physical Science.
